body: Can confirm this with github version 2a69139aa7f609e439c24a46754252a5f9d37500 (1.0.0 release) on OSX
The problem seems to be solved on master ( 0e43d67602096a5c4aeab4632579bc56cf692553 )
confirm it's fixed on 0e43d67
Anyway to force homebrew to upgrade to master since its stuck on the 1.0.0 cut?

So, master is 1.1.0-dev, and we won't release it for a while. Could you try with the current HEAD of the v1.0.x branch ? d7ff4ff40071d2b486a052183e3e9f9382afb745 that is. If it still happens there, we need to figure out which commit in master actually fixes it, and backport that to the v1.0.x branch.
Just tried it, it also fails with d7ff4ff

Can you describe a bit more what is it you're doing to test this from git directly ? I just tried building d7ff4ff40071d2b486a052183e3e9f9382afb745 on Mac, and the hello world's greeter server, and everything's fine on my end.

We need a bit more data.

It compiles w/o --no-as-needed and --as-needed but then I get the pthread_mutex_lock assertion failure

```
➜  helloworld git:(d7ff4ff) ✗ vim Makefile 
➜  helloworld git:(d7ff4ff) ✗ make
g++ helloworld.pb.o helloworld.grpc.pb.o greeter_client.o -L/usr/local/lib `pkg-config --libs grpc++ grpc` -Wl -lgrpc++_reflection -Wl -lprotobuf -lpthread -ldl -o greeter_client

g++ helloworld.pb.o helloworld.grpc.pb.o greeter_async_client.o -L/usr/local/lib `pkg-config --libs grpc++ grpc` -Wl -lgrpc++_reflection -Wl -lprotobuf -lpthread -ldl -o greeter_async_client

g++ helloworld.pb.o helloworld.grpc.pb.o greeter_async_client2.o -L/usr/local/lib `pkg-config --libs grpc++ grpc` -Wl -lgrpc++_reflection -Wl -lprotobuf -lpthread -ldl -o greeter_async_client2
g++ -std=c++11 -I/usr/local/include -pthread  -c -o greeter_async_server.o greeter_async_server.cc
g++ helloworld.pb.o helloworld.grpc.pb.o greeter_async_server.o -L/usr/local/lib `pkg-config --libs grpc++ grpc` -Wl -lgrpc++_reflection -Wl -lprotobuf -lpthread -ldl -o greeter_async_server
➜  helloworld git:(d7ff4ff) ✗ ./greeter_server
E0825 11:17:15.768300000 140735216762880 sync_posix.c:51] assertion failed: pthread_mutex_lock(mu) == 0
[1]    8910 abort      ./greeter_server
➜  helloworld git:(d7ff4ff) ✗ 
```

I've also run into this. The issue doesn't seem to exist in the common parent of 0e43d67 and the v1.0.0 tag. Git bisect suggests it was introduced in a469e5d, which just changes library links.

In fact, it also happens on current master (c931305). So there doesn't seem to be a fix already created. Perhaps it's something to do with grpc_unsecure?

After some investigation, I believe the issue is that a469e5d adds the grpc library object files directly into the grpc++ library (so you don't have to link against grpc when using grpc++).

The problem is that some of the grpc object files have the same names as grpc++ object files (eg: time.o from time.c and time.o from time.cc). The linker only includes one of them (and warns about this). However, you don't get actual linker errors (unresolved symbols, etc) because it _also_ links to grpc. But you almost certainly get duplicate global variables this way, which is probably where the error on this ticket comes from (the mutex storage that is initialised is not the mutex storage that is used).

I've seen similar issues in the Windows build system (where it _does_ cause linker errors), probably from the same commit. Partially reverting a469e5d (removing all the added "src/core/*_/_.c" lines) fixes the issue. Renaming some of the C++ or C source files should also work (in which case, libgrpc++ should no longer link to libgrpc).
So if that's the case, we're making sure we have no more duplicated filenames at all, in the v1.0.x.

@liuempire if you just want a quick build fix, `git revert a469e5d` will do it. However, I think you may end up being unable to use grpc++_unsecure without OpenSSL.

@nicolasnoble that should fix both the Windows (vsprojects) and Mac (Makefile) build systems. Although the Makefile should also be changed to not link grpc++[_unsecure] to grpc[_unsecure].
I can confirm it exists on OS X El Captain, even in current 'master' branch. The workaround is to static link libgrpc++.a and libgrpc.a archive in Xcode or CMake.

As of today, this issue does still exist in master on Mac OS X 10.11, not sure about macOS 10.12. I'm not sure how to utilize the static link workaround with the current examples, is there any additional info on that or other workarounds. Any ideas when a fix might get into the tree? We're trying to use this on Mac, Windows and Linux and right now the Mac can't even run the example "hello world" app.

@advenioinc Here is part of my CMakeLists.txt
`set(PROJ_DEPS ${BREW_HOME}/lib/libgrpc++.a ${BREW_HOME}/lib/libgrpc.a z protobuf 
  mongocxx bsoncxx mongoc-1.0 
  bson-1.0 ssl crypto iec61850 ${RT_LIB} pthread dl)`
that the variable PROJ_DEPS was putted in target's target_link_libraries()
`add_executable(${PROJECT_NAME} common/Variables.cpp main.cpp)`
`target_link_libraries(${PROJECT_NAME} ${PROJ_DEPS})`
We just use the absolute path of grpc static libraries and leave other dynamic library by use their name.

and for Xcode, you can set 'Other linker flags' in Project Settings like this
`/usr/local/lib/libgrpc++.a /usr/local/lib/libgrpc.a z protobuf 
  mongocxx bsoncxx mongoc-1.0 bson-1.0 ssl crypto iec61850 rt pthread dl`

macOS Sierra 10.12

I compiled with the make command. You need to be sure to run make uninstall or something to remove all old versions of your system. If you do not then you get this kind of error. It took me all weekend to find that out.
So you installed manually or with brew?

1. Dowload protobuf, extract it cd into it
   ./configure
   make uninstall
2. Install grpc
   git clone -b $(curl -L http://grpc.io/release) https://github.com/grpc/grpc
   cd grpc
   git submodule update --init
   rm -r ./third_party/nanopb
   git checkout f89a4a1
   cd third_party
   cd protobuf
   git checkout master
   cd ../..
   make
   su
   make install
   cd third_party/protobuf
   make install
   exit
   cd examples/cpp/helloworld
   make
